isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 MODEL - HEATER AND AIR CONDITIONER (CAB) - TROUBLESHOOTING

item.para: Before beginning these test procedures, make sure the vehicle batteries are at 75% state of charge (SOC) or higher. This represents an open circuit voltage (OCV) of 13.4 volts. Batteries with an OCV of 12 volts or less are either completely discharged or have a dead cell.
Before beginning these test procedures, check any light or indicator lamp filaments that are suspected of being open (burned out). This is done to avoid unnecessary extensive circuit checks.

Before beginning these test procedures, inspect all connectors for loose or damaged pins, wires, etc. Refer to TEST EQUIPMENT AND CONNECTOR REPAIR section in GROUP 08 - ELECTRICAL in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

When the technician determines that a fuse is blown, while checking its condition, he is directed to locate the cause of the overload condition and to repair it. While no further instruction on this procedure is listed in the diagnostic tables, the common procedure is as follows: isolate sections of the circuit, by disconnecting connectors, and measure the resistance to ground to find the circuit that is shorted to ground. Then locate the damaged spot in the wire or connector and repair.

Diagnostics for circuits that are malfunctioning by sticking in the on position are generally not covered in detail. It is assumed that the technician knows to check for a malfunctioning switch, relay, or solenoid.

entry.para: Does the blower run in either the low, medium, or high speed position?
Remove heater control relay (463)/R5, move key switch to ignition position, and at circuit 13T measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 13T or 13H, then repair.
At relay socket (463)/R5, measure voltage from circuit 13T to 13-GT.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 13-GT, 5-GB, 75-GC, 75-GB, 11-GN or 11-GB, to cab ground, then repair.
At (B2) battery stud, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage at (B2) battery stud, then repair.
Remove fuse F1-C and check for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition, then repair. Replace fuse.
At F1-C circuit 14Z measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14W or 14Z, then repair.
Re-install fuse F1-C and at relay socket (463)/R5, measure voltage from circuit 75A to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75A, then repair.
Bench test heater control relay (463)/R5 by measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87A.
Bench test heater control relay (463)/R5 by applying +12 volts to pin 86, ground to pin 85, and measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87.
Re-install (463)/R5 and disconnect switch (83). Move key switch to ignition position and at (83) circuit 75B, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75B, then repair.
Test blower control switch (83) by placing switch in low position, and measuring resistance from switch terminal B to L and B to A/C.
(83), term. B to L and B to A/C.
Test blower control switch (83) by placing switch in medium position, and measuring resistance from switch terminal B to L, B to M, and B to A/C.
(83) term. B to L, B to M and B to A/C.
Test blower control switch (83) by placing switch in high position, and measuring resistance from switch terminal B to H, B to M, and B to A/C.
(83), term. B to H, B to M, and B to A/C.
Re-install blower switch (83). Move key switch to on position. Does blower motor run at low speed when blower switch is set to low position?
Disconnect conn. (45) and with key switch in ignition position and blower switch in low speed position, measure voltage from circuit 75C [coming from (83)] to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75C, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (45) and disconnect resistor and thermofuse assembly (27). With key switch in ignition position and blower switch in low position, measure voltage from circuit 75C to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75C, then repair.
At blower resistor and thermofuse assembly (27), measure resistance from terminal 1 to 2.
At blower resistor and thermofuse assembly (27), measure resistance from terminal 2 to 3.
Reconnect blower resistor, and disconnect conn. (44). With key switch in ignition position and blower switch in low speed position, at (44) circuit 75T [coming from (27)], measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75T, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (44) and remove high speed relay (462)/R2. At circuit 75T, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75T, then repair.
Bench test high speed relay (462)/R2 by measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87A.
Bench test high speed relay (462)/R2 by applying +12 volts to pin 86, ground to pin 85, and measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87.
Move key switch to ignition position, blower switch to high speed position, and at (462)/R2 circuit 75H, measure volts to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75H, then repair.
With switches still set, at (462)/R2 measure voltage from circuit 75H to 75-GB.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 75-GB, 11-GN or 11-GB to right cab gnd. (404), then repair.
At (462)/R2 install a test jumper from circuit 75F to 75-GB. Disconnect conn. (44) and at circuit 75F [coming from (462)/R2], measure resistance to ground.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 75F, then repair.
At connector (44) measure resistance from circuit 75-G [going to (404)] to ground.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 75-G or 11-G to cab gnd. stud, then repair.
Reconnect (44) and disconnect circuit 75F from blower motor (39). Move key switch to ignition position and blower switch to low position, and at 75F measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75F, then repair.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 75-G, then repair.
With ignition key in off position, reconnect circuit 75F. Move key switch to ignition position and with blower switch in low speed position, does blower run?
Remove medium speed relay (462)/R3, move key switch to ignition position, and move blower switch to medium speed. At circuit 75N, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75N, then repair.
With switches still set, at (462)/R3 measure voltage from circuit 75N to 75-GC.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 75-GC, 75-GB, 11-GN or 11-GB to right cab gnd. stud (404), then repair.
At relay socket (462)/R3 and circuit 75D, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75D, then repair.
Bench test medium speed relay (462)/R3 by measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87A.
Bench test medium speed relay (462)/R3 by applying +12V to pin 86, ground to 85, and measuring resistance from pin 30 to 87.

Disconnect conn. (44), re-install medium speed relay (462)/R3, move key switch to ignition position, and blower switch to low speed position. At (44) circuit 75M [coming from (462)/R3] measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75M, then repair.
Disconnect connector (27) and reconnect connector (44). At connector (27) circuit 75M, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75N, then repair.
Remove fuse F1-A and check for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition, then repair. Replace fuse.
Re-install fuse F1-A, and at circuit 14X, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14X, then repair.
Reconnect (27) and remove high speed relay (462)/R2. At (462)/R2 circuit 75, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 75, then repair.
Re-install high speed relay (462)/R2. Heater blower circuits check good.
